learning_outcomes.description: develop a critical and inquisitive perspective to study religion, peace and violence
develop skills in close reading and summary of complex concepts
recognize diverse forms of violence and harm and social goods and well-being.
acquire a broad familiarity with key concepts and ideas in the study of religion, violence and peace
understand conflict, violence and peace as multi-layered and historically and socially multifaceted
develop the knowledge base and analytical skills to examine issues and conflicts around religion and in society today
bring empirical evidence to bear upon theoretical scholarship and public opinion
critically analyze evidence and arguments from a range of sources and synthesize material and ideas clearly in speech and in writing
frame and articulate a position and provide an argument on a given topic in relation to relevant scholarly debates
conduct research independently, demonstrating reasoned thought, creativity and a high quality of expression

assessments.due_date:
5/03/2026

Journal assignments begin in Week 2 with the first entry due in Week 3. For a schedule of readings and questions see the library resources page.
assessments.task_description:
Reading responses of 100-150 words (+/- 10 per cent) are due starting in week 2. Students are to respond to the assigned question and reading. Each entry should take its topic from questions that will be listed on the library resources page (see Blackboard) that will be based upon the week's readings.

There are 9 scheduled diary entries and students are expected to complete 8 of these (that is, there is one entry that provides a point of leeway and flexibility). The maximum total grade possible for students completing 8 or 9 entries is 20, dependent on the grades assigned to each entry according to the marking criteria. There are no bonus marks for completing 9 entries.

Students will be expected to complete the required journal entries over the course of the semester. Journal entries begin in Week 2. Each journal entry must be submitted at 2pm on the day of the lectures, and they must be submitted via journal Turnitin links on the Blackboard page. 

It is important to maintain a consistent effort for this task over the semester.

A maximum of 20 marks will be awarded for journal entries (2.5 mark per journal entry) if entries are completed and submitted on time and demonstrate preparation (mainly though knowledge of readings). Responses that do not respond to the question or relate to the reading will receive a grade of 1, as per the assessment criteria. If 5 or fewer diary entries are completed, the student will receive 0 diary entry marks.

Journal assignments begin in Week 2. Entries are due at 2pm on the day of the lecture the week following.

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Each journal entry must be submitted within one week of lectures, and they must be submitted via journal Turnitin links on the Blackboard page.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.due_date:
23/04/2026 10:00 am

The deferred exam is scheduled for week 9, Thursday 30 April at 12noon, room TBC. Official approval required. The exam MUST be written in person.
assessments.task_description:
All external students MUST complete this exam in-person.

Aim: The midterm will test your knowledge of the lecture and tutorial reading content.

Preparation: The exam consists of multiple choice questions and written response questions.

*To prepare for the multiple choice questions, students are expected to attend/view lectures and to have completed the required readings for the tutorials.

*To prepare for the written response questions, students are expected to conduct independent research based on the supplied sample questions and readings available on the library resources page for this course accessible through Blackboard and the UQ library page. Students will be asked to choose 2 essay topics from a supplied list and to respond to the questions using at least 4 sources from the assigned readings. Students will be expected to refer to the author's name or the title of the work in their responses, but students are NOT expected to provide full bibliographic information during the exam. One question may relate to the excursion.

AI: This assessment task evaluates the student's abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of artificial intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses in advance and during the exam is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.e (AI).
assessments.submission_guidelines: submit in person to invigilator after completing the exam
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
Aim: The take-home exam aims to simulate a real-world problem scenario of identifying speech/text that is extremist or peace-building, and to evaluate the content and make decisions that have will have significant implications. You will be tasked with learning and applying a coding scheme to a chosen text (e.g. political speech, treatise, or manifesto) and to evaluate how that text is potentially harmful or helpful to community relations in diverse multicultural societies such as Australia. In the simulation you will be tasked with making evaluations and judgements that have significant social impact, showing how you arrive at your judgement with an array of tools and your own critical analysis.

AI: Students will learn to use AI tools to facilitate coding through the required method/schemata but students must demonstrate their own analytical judgements independent of AI in completing the required questions.

Failing Criteria and Academic Misconduct

Fabrication or misrepresentation of sources will result in an automatic maximum grade of 2 for this assessment, regardless of performance in other criteria. This includes but is not limited to: citing non-existent sources or attributing false quotes to real sources. Such issues demonstrate failure to meet the core learning outcomes for the course and may also be referred for academic misconduct
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1.Thinking about religion, violence and peace

This lecture will introduce the course and assessment expectations.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1.Thinking about religion, violence and peace This lecture will introduce the course and assessment expectations.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Suffering and the Problem of Evil

Many religious traditions have developed from the raw experience of suffering, and today's conflicts are often rooted in suffering and generate suffering. This lecture will explore how religions have responded to suffering and evil, and how it animates human conflict today.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 2: Suffering and the Problem of Evil
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Suffering and the Problem of Evil Many religious traditions have developed from the raw experience of suffering, and today's conflicts are often rooted in suffering and generate suffering. This lecture will explore how religions have responded to suffering and evil, and how it animates human conflict today.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Secular violence

The modern idea of religious violence is a just that: a modern idea, forged in the fires of the Enlightenment in Europe. This lecture will challenge students to rethink their assumptions about religious violence through critically analysing the formation of the secular through the development of the modern nationstate that have given rise to the "myth of religious violence".

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: Secular violence The modern idea of religious violence is a just that: a modern idea, forged in the fires of the Enlightenment in Europe. This lecture will challenge students to rethink their assumptions about religious violence through critically analysing the formation of the secular through the development of the modern nationstate that have given rise to the "myth of religious violence".

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: Visit to Queensland Holocaust Museum

External students are welcome to attend but must notify the course coordinator 7 days in advance.

The tour and presentations begin at 11:30am on Thursday 19 March. Please be sure to arrive by 11:20 so that you are not late. Students are to make their own way to the Queensland Holocaust Museum: 168 Charlotte St, Brisbane City QLD 4000. Transportation directions from UQ and further information on the site visit will be given to students at the start of term. This site visit is in place of the on campus lecture and tutorial. Diary marks will be given based on attendance.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09

Students are to make their own way to the Queensland Holocaust Museum: 168 Charlotte St, Brisbane City QLD 4000. Transportation directions from UQ and further information on the site visit will be given to students at the start of term. This site visit is in place of the on campus lecture and tutorial. Diary marks will be given based on attendance.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: New Religious Movements & Conspirituality

Theorists surmised that the late 20th century would see the demise of religion in public life, but religion persisted through some dramatic developments and events. New Religious Movements (NRMs) exploded onto the scene and with a few instances of violence, became swept up into wider narratives and moral panics around religion. This lecture will explore the relationship between NRMs, violence, and wider social and political responses, giving rise to thinking more widely about religion in society today. We also discuss the emergence of conspirituality, where spirituality meets conspiracy theory.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5: New Religious Movements & Conspirituality Theorists surmised that the late 20th century would see the demise of religion in public life, but religion persisted through some dramatic developments and events. New Religious Movements (NRMs) exploded onto the scene and with a few instances of violence, became swept up into wider narratives and moral panics around religion. This lecture will explore the relationship between NRMs, violence, and wider social and political responses, giving rise to thinking more widely about religion in society today. We also discuss the emergence of conspirituality, where spirituality meets conspiracy theory.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6: New Atheism

This lecture will explore theories of religious violence, focusing on New Atheist arguments and contrasting these with Rene Girard's theory of violence found in memetic desire. The lecture aims to develop students' critical reasoning and analytical skills, encouraging students to evaluate arguments about religion and violence based on the underlying assumptions implicit within. That is, explanations of religion and violence are always theories about what religion is, something that there is much disagreement about.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09

That is, explanations of religion and violence are always theories about what religion is, something that there is much disagreement about.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8: Mid-Term Exam

Information on the midterm exam will be provided in the first week of lectures. Please consult the Course Profile and attend lecture or view the recorded lecture for more information. Students must attend this exam in person. Students who have an approved absence must write the deferred exam at the scheduled time one week later or receive a 0.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9: Social Justice and Climate Justice

Social Justice: This lecture explores social justice in an age of wokism and anti-wokism. It explores the political movements behind wokism and push-back against social justice campaigns. Drawing on historical and contemporary examples of social justice campaigns related to settler colonialism and social injustice, this lecture will challenge students to think about social justice from a range of perspectives and consider the recurring structural impediments to equality and justice.

Climate Justice: This lecture will explore environmental activism from the perspective of different religious and secular outlooks, showing how humans relate to nature and recognising that climate destruction will exacerbate political conflicts and economic disparities in the future.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 9: Social Justice and Climate Justice Social Justice: This lecture explores social justice in an age of wokism and anti-wokism. It explores the political movements behind wokism and push-back against social justice campaigns. Drawing on historical and contemporary examples of social justice campaigns related to settler colonialism and social injustice, this lecture will challenge students to think about social justice from a range of perspectives and consider the recurring structural impediments to equality and justice. Climate Justice: This lecture will explore environmental activism from the perspective of different religious and secular outlooks, showing how humans relate to nature and recognising that climate destruction will exacerbate political conflicts and economic disparities in the future.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10: Religious Nationalism

This lecture introduces students to religious nationalism as it has marked contemporary politics around the world. From the rise of the Moral Majority in the US to Hindu Nationalism in India, religious nationalism illustrates how religion and politics are far from separate but intimately entangled.

Learning outcomes: L10
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 10: Religious Nationalism This lecture introduces students to religious nationalism as it has marked contemporary politics around the world. From the rise of the Moral Majority in the US to Hindu Nationalism in India, religious nationalism illustrates how religion and politics are far from separate but intimately entangled.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11: Hate & Social Cohesion

This lecture explores the roots of hate and shows its harm to social cohesion and to flourishing democratic multicultural societies. It discusses Islamophobia, racism, and anti-semitism in contemporary and historical context, giving students an understandng of the history of the terms and their legal status.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 11: Hate & Social Cohesion This lecture explores the roots of hate and shows its harm to social cohesion and to flourishing democratic multicultural societies. It discusses Islamophobia, racism, and anti-semitism in contemporary and historical context, giving students an understandng of the history of the terms and their legal status.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12: Gender, Freedom, and Oppression

Does religion oppress women? What role does fashion play in subverting patriarchal norms? How is modesty a political act? In this lecture we explore the relationship between gender and violence through several case studies. We are first challenged to consider the feminist project through embodiment, agency, tradition and modernity within female piety movements in Judaism, Christianity and Islam. We then explore further examples from India, Pakistan and Afghanistan.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09

We then explore further examples from India, Pakistan and Afghanistan.
